author: By Neil Vigdor and Christina Morales
title: 4 People Are Killed in a Shooting Outside Columbus, Ohio
description: Three bodies were found in an apartment in West Jefferson, and a fourth was found outside, the police said.
content: Four people were killed in a shooting on Monday outside Columbus, Ohio, the authorities said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: To Prevent Evictions, End Moratoriums
description: Philadelphia is demonstrating how cities can help tenants and landlords.
content: Halting most evictions during the coronavirus pandemic was a necessary act of emergency medicine. Federal, state and local moratoriums allowed millions of Americans to stay in their homes when they couldn’t afford to pay rent. But that success is now at risk of unraveling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio, John Eligon and Adeel Hassan
title: A Timeline of What Has Happened in the Year Since George Floyd’s Death
description: A look back at what has transpired in the year since Mr. Floyd’s murder reveals a country both struggling to confront it history of racial division and continuing to succumb to it.
content: George Floyd, a 46-year-old African-American man, is killed on a street corner in Minneapolis after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by Derek Chauvin and other officers responding to a forgery call. Darnella Frazier, a 17-year-old, turns on her cellphone to capture video of Mr. Chauvin, who is white, using his knee to pin Mr. Floyd by his neck. Mr. Floyd is heard repeatedly saying, “I can’t breathe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Punk Rock Teens
description: Are you in a band? If you’re not, can you imagine yourself joining one?
content: The band featured above, the Linda Lindas, is made up of four Asian and Latina teens and tweens who last week had a clip of a recent performance of their song “Racist, Sexist Boy” at a branch of the Los Angeles Public Library go viral. Did you see it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linsey McGoey
title: Why Billionaires Like Bill Gates Can’t Fix the Problems They Helped Create
description: The Gates divorce is prompting people to ask hard questions about the foundation. That's good.
content: Bill Gates hasn’t changed. His public image has. Mr. Gates’s personal behavior and his troubling comanagement of the Gates Foundation are being reported more openly. The question is why it took so long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: What Happened to Novak Djokovic’s Mission to Transform Pro Tennis?
description: The Professional Tennis Players Association had a flashy introduction last summer, but it has done little else. The players who created the sport’s original unions have some advice.
content: Nine months ago, a group of tennis players started an organization aimed at giving them more say in how their sport operates and divides the roughly $2 billion the game generates annually. A group of former players who brought tennis into the modern era of sports commerce have been watching their work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: An Indian couple is under investigation over a chartered flight linked to their wedding.
description: The bride and groom told SpiceJet that they were taking guests on a postnuptial joy ride. Then video emerged of violations of Covid-19 restrictions.
content: The authorities in southern India are investigating a couple who are reported to have chartered a plane and performed a marriage ritual in midair in front of scores of guests, a breach of Covid-19 guidelines in a country that is being devastated by a second wave of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Viren
title: The Native Scholar Who Wasn’t
description: More than a decade ago, a prominent academic was exposed for having faked her Cherokee ancestry. Why has her career continued to thrive?
content: It was a Thursday morning last September, and J. Kehaulani Kauanui had just woken up. She was reading a story on her phone in bed, a confession written by a woman named Jessica Krug, when, quite suddenly, it yanked her into the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How the Mideast Conflict Is Blowing Up the Region, the Democratic Party and Every Synagogue in America
description: President Biden must  re-energize the possibility of a two-state solution.
content: Lord knows, I sympathize with President Biden’s desire to avoid getting dragged into mediating the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But the 11 days of fighting between Israel and Hamas made something crystal clear to me: Unless we preserve at least the potential of a two-state solution, the one-state reality that would emerge in its place won’t just blow up Israel, the West Bank and Gaza; it could very well blow up the Democratic Party and every Jewish organization and synagogue in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The C.D.C. stopped investigating most breakthrough infections among fully vaccinated individuals.
content: It has been five months since the first Covid-19 vaccine was administered in the U.S., and so far the data on vaccinations suggests that they are highly effective. Breakthrough infections, which happen after a person is fully vaccinated, are few and far between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Iran Talks Loom as a New Test of Biden’s Israel Ties
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken visited Israel to talk about Gaza and the Palestinians, but heard a stern message about nuclear talks with Tehran.
content: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took a moment on Tuesday to thank the Biden administration for its support during his country’s 11-day conflict with Hamas in Gaza — and then abruptly changed the subject, and his tone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Americans abroad can now enter the U.S. on expired passports.
description: The State Department said it would allow many Americans who have been unable to renew their travel documents overseas to use their old ones to enter the country.
content: American citizens abroad who saw their passports expire during the Covid-19 pandemic are now able to return to the United States before renewing their travel documents, a shift of policy announced by the State Department on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Darnella Frazier, the teenager who recorded George Floyd’s murder, speaks out.
description: “I still hold the weight and trauma of what I witnessed a year ago,” she said. “A part of my childhood was taken from me.”
content: Darnella Frazier, the young woman who took out her cellphone on a Minneapolis street to record a video of a white police officer as he knelt on George Floyd’s neck that would ricochet around the world, released a powerful statement on Tuesday addressing the first anniversary of Mr. Floyd’s death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Eurovision-Winning Band Leader Did Not Use Drugs, Broadcaster Says
description: Damiano David of the Italian rock band Maneskin hunched over a table in a sniffing motion during the show’s finale, fueling speculation of drug use.
content: The vernacular of rock ’n’ roll frequently revolves around drugs, but when the winning band’s lead singer hunched over a table in a sniffing motion during this year’s Eurovision Song Contest, the showcase was shaken by speculation of cocaine use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: The Caribbean, united by tourism, is divided by Covid.
description: On the glassy blue waters surrounding the U.S. Virgin Islands, catamarans and pleasure yachts have packed the shoreline for the past year — a scene so busy and crowded that it would have been notable even before the pandemic.
content: On the glassy blue waters surrounding the U.S. Virgin Islands, catamarans and pleasure yachts have packed the shoreline for the past year — a scene so busy and crowded that it would have been notable even before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Endless Curiosity of Chris Thile
description: The 40-year-old mandolinist has found inspiration in groups, and as the host of “Live From Here.” “Laysongs” is his most directly personal work yet.
content: At his first in-person performance before a New York audience in over a year, the mandolinist Chris Thile spent a lot of time with his instrument on his lap, listening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Emily Schmall
title: Indian Police Visit Twitter Offices as Modi Goes on Pandemic Offense
description: The visit sent a clear message that India’s powerful ruling party is becoming increasingly upset with the company.
content: The officers from India’s elite antiterrorism police unit descended after dusk on the New Delhi offices of Twitter, with television news cameras in tow. Their mission: Start an argument over fake news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Asian Homeowners Were Targeted in Burglary Ring, Prosecutors Say
description: Eight men were charged in federal court with burglarizing 50 homes in four states after identifying the residents as Asian.
content: Eight men targeted Asian homeowners for theft as part of an intricate multistate burglary ring that preyed mainly on restaurant owners in New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania and Delaware, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Lakers Weren’t Ready for the Moment. Devin Booker Was.
description: Booker, the Phoenix Suns’ All-Star guard, is already showing the poise and determination of a playoff regular in his first postseason.
content: The roots of everything that the Suns are now — a winning team, a franchise with championship hopes — date to 2015, when Phoenix made Devin Booker the 13th overall pick of the N.B.A. draft. For his first couple of seasons in Phoenix, he played in relative anonymity. The Suns were a terrible team. The closest Booker got to the playoffs was watching other players celebrate big wins on television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A Lost Brontë Library Surfaces
description: A trove of manuscripts acquired from the Brontë family in the 19th century, all but unseen for the past century, will be auctioned at Sotheby’s.
content: Brontë artifacts have a way of making dramatic reappearances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Spend Your Guaranteed Income
description: It’s your money; spend it on whatever you need and enjoy the peace of mind.
content: “Let the money give you peace of mind,” says Brenita Burns, 38, who was one of 110 low-income Black mothers in Jackson, Miss., who received $1,000 a month last year as part of a guaranteed-income project called Magnolia Mother’s Trust. When Burns was accepted into the program, she hoped to put some of the money toward paying off her $20,000 in student loans. But by the time her first check arrived in March 2020, the country was shutting down. The first things she bought were groceries and a laptop for her 10-year-old son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dexter Palmer
title: A Novel Imagines a Victorian England Ruled by France
description: “The Kingdoms,” by Natasha Pulley, follows an amnesiac protagonist caught up in an attempt to change history.
content: THE KINGDOMSBy Natasha Pulley
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: ‘I Am So Freaked Out. I Can’t Even Get My Mind Around It.’
description: After 21 runners died during an ultramarathon, will the endurance sport look inward and explore whether it has become too extreme?
content: Ultrarunning has never experienced a day like Saturday, when 21 runners died as a storm descended on a high mountain pass during a 62-mile race in northwestern China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: How the G.O.P. Primary for Mayor Turned 2 Friends Into Bitter Rivals
description: Two long-shots, Curtis Sliwa, the founder of the Guardian Angels, and Fernando Mateo, a restaurateur, are in a heated fight to be their party’s nominee.
content: The two Republicans running for mayor of New York City used to be friends. They are both first-time candidates, long shots for the job and tabloid fixtures who perk up when they see a news camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss and Peter Eavis
title: Exxon Mobil Faces Off Against Activist Investors on Climate Change
description: The oil company will hold a contested election for four board seats at its annual shareholders meeting on Wednesday.
content: HOUSTON — Exxon Mobil’s management will face a big challenge over its climate change policies at an annual shareholder meeting on Wednesday as activists contest the election of one-third of the company’s board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: The Cummings Chronicles: The Can’t-Miss Sequel
description: Once Boris Johnson’s closest adviser, Dominic Cummings is expected to deliver scorching testimony in Parliament on Wednesday about the government’s handling of the pandemic.
content: LONDON — A year ago this week, a brusque, defiant figure in shirt sleeves appeared in the sun-dappled garden behind 10 Downing Street to give one of the most extraordinary news conferences in recent British political history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Poets Risk Their Lives to Save Myanmar’s Soul Against Junta
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 25, 2021.
content: “The people with weapons are afraid of pen-wielding hands.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Epic Case Against Apple Wraps Up
description: It’s now in a judge’s hands.
content: For the past three weeks, Apple has been defending itself in federal court against claims brought by Epic Games, the maker of the blockbuster video game Fortnite, that Apple abuses its power by charging app makers unfairly high commissions to appear in its App Store. Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers said she hoped to deliver a verdict in mid-August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Gunter
title: Women Can Have a Better Menopause. Here’s How.
description: Women often experience the hormonal transition of midlife in a shroud of misinformation and shame. We deserve more.
content: Menopause has long been treated as a pre-death, a metamorphosis from a woman to a crone with her exit ticket already punched. This is because a woman’s worth was measured by her reproductive ability and by extension her femininity, as defined by a narrow, misogynistic standard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: Gunshots and a panic at George Floyd Square.
description: Dozens of activists and bystanders paying their respects at the site where Mr. Floyd was killed ran from the area on Tuesday morning after a series of loud bangs rang out.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Dozens of activists and bystanders paying their respects at George Floyd Square in Minneapolis ran from the area on Tuesday after a series of loud bangs rang out, raising fears that shots were being fired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Scrolling While the World Burns
description: Richard Flanagan’s new novel, “The Living Sea of Waking Dreams,” urges us to pay attention to the things that matter.
content: THE LIVING SEA OF WAKING DREAMSBy Richard Flanagan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italy to Try Four Egyptian Agents in Killing of Italian Student
description: The agents will be tried in absentia in Rome in the death of Giulio Regeni, who had been doing research in Egypt and is now a symbol for human rights in Italy.
content: Prosecutors in Italy can try four Egyptian security agents on charges of kidnapping, torturing and murdering an Italian doctoral student whose brutalized body was found on the outskirts of Cairo in 2016, a judge in Rome ruled on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Anton Troianovski and Michael Crowley
title: Biden and Putin to Meet in Mid-June, in a Summit Fraught With Tensions
description: The meeting comes at the worst point in Russian-American relations since the fall of the Soviet Union about 30 years ago.
content: President Biden and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have agreed to meet on June 16 in Geneva for a face-to-face encounter that comes at a time of fast-deteriorating relations over Ukraine, cyberattacks and a raft of new nuclear weapons Mr. Putin is deploying. The summit is the first in-person meeting between the two leaders since Mr. Biden became president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Judge Declares Mistrial in Murder Case Against Brother of Simone Biles
description: Jurors told the judge they had seen legal briefs among the evidence in the case of Tevin Biles-Thomas, who is accused of killing three people. The trial has unfolded as his sister, the U.S. gymnast, trains for the Tokyo Olympics.
content: A Cleveland judge declared a mistrial on Tuesday in the murder trial of Tevin Biles-Thomas, the brother of the Olympic gymnastics champion Simone Biles, who was charged last year in the fatal shooting of three people at a New Year’s Eve party in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ayobami Adebayo
title: Anita Diamant Continues the Fight for Menstrual Justice
description: “Period. End of Sentence.” makes a cultural and political argument for less shame and more support and celebration of women’s reproductive realities.
content: PERIOD. END OF SENTENCE. A New Chapter in the Fight for Menstrual Justice By Anita Diamant
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: The Caribbean Conundrum: United by Tourists, Divided by Covid
description: The pandemic struck these islands unequally. What does this mean for tourism, a major economic driver for the entire region? The answer is unique, just like the islands.
content: On the glassy blue waters surrounding the U.S. Virgin Islands, catamarans and pleasure yachts have packed the shoreline for the past year — a scene so busy and crowded, it’s unimaginable, even before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: black midi’s Music Embraces the Extremes
description: For its second album, the British band got louder — and quieter, too.
content: The band black midi makes complex music with a simple goal: “Drama,” Geordie Greep, its guitarist and main singer, said via a video interview from the band’s rehearsal space in London. “We’re thinking about how to make something as thrilling as possible, how to keep the tension there always.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From Slave Traders to the Savoy Hotel
description: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: THE LEDGER AND THE CHAIN: How Domestic Slave Traders Shaped America, by Joshua D. Rothman. (Basic, $35.) Accounts of American slavery often overlook the central role of the traders who profited. Rothman’s history focuses on three of the biggest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Nicholas Fandos
title: George Floyd’s Family Meets With Biden Amid Push for Police Reform
description: The family said the president vowed to pass a police reform bill and promised justice not only for Mr. Floyd but for a nation still reeling from a year of killings and protests.
content: WASHINGTON — In a private meeting at the White House on Tuesday, President Biden renewed the promise he made to the family of George Floyd just hours after a Minneapolis police officer was convicted of murder in his death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shahzia Sikander
title: Shahzia Sikander: What We Believe About Culture
description: Art helps reverse stereotypes and creates a path for better representation in a complex and dynamic world.
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we believe? You can read more essays by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ruffled Feathers Among the Birders of Central Park
description: “Birding Bob” knows how to find the birds of New York City. But some people aren’t happy about how he does it.
content: If you grab binoculars and head to Central Park in New York, you may see a warbler, a robin and Robert DeCandido, also known as “Birding Bob.” If you can’t spot him, you’ll definitely hear him. Among dedicated birders, some consider his use of recorded bird calls a disturbance to birds and bird-watchers alike, while others see him as an eager advocate for the natural world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamilton Cain
title: An Invigorating Novel About Faith, Family and Falling From Grace
description: Monica West’s “Revival Season” takes readers under the big tent of Southern Baptist life.
content: REVIVAL SEASONBy Monica West304 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: A.P. Begins Review of Social Media Policy After Journalist’s Firing
description: The news agency known for unbiased journalism faces criticism from its own staff after a young news associate was dismissed.
content: The Associated Press has started a review of its social media policy after more than 150 staff members publicly condemned the firing of a young journalist for violating that policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: A Self-Styled ‘Troublemaker’ Creates a Different Paris Museum
description: Contemporary art owned by the billionaire François Pinault is displayed beneath the rotunda of the Bourse de Commerce and frescoes of a colonialist past.
content: PARIS — François Pinault, the French billionaire, has never had much time for convention. “Avoid the paths already trodden,” has been his motto. Bored with acquiring Impressionist or Cubist works with surefire credentials, he said to himself four decades ago: “It’s impossible that we have become so stupid today that there are no human beings alive capable of creating tomorrow’s masterpieces.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Is Your School’s Dress Code Outdated?
description: Many students and parents at a Florida high school say administrators are using outdated dress codes to police the way girls dress. Is your school’s policy fair?
content: Does your school have a dress code? What are its rules? Do you consider them fair? Do you think they apply equally to both male and female students? Why or why not?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Jade-Snow Joachim
title: George Floyd, Moderna, Brood X: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Kristen Clarke is the first Senate-confirmed woman of color to lead the Justice Dept.’s civil rights division.
description: Ms. Clarke was confirmed by a vote of 51 to 48, largely along party lines.
content: The Senate on Tuesday voted to confirm Kristen Clarke to lead the Justice Department’s civil rights division, making her the first woman of color to be confirmed by the Senate to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Despite gains against the virus, the C.D.C. director says unvaccinated people remain at risk.
description: Vaccinated Americans may be looking forward to crowded beaches and packed backyard barbecues, getting back to what Dr. Rochelle Walensky described as “something closer to normal.”
content: As Memorial Day weekend approaches, the head of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention offered a hopeful message mixed with caution on Tuesday for Americans planning to celebrate the traditional beginning of summer with friends and family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How Michel Foucault Lost the Left and Won the Right
description: The right learned to love relativism and the left learned to love power.
content: One of the strange things about the last year in Western political debate is how rarely the name of the departed philosopher Michel Foucault came up — and not for want of opportunity. One of Foucault’s key concepts, “biopolitics,” an account of the way that modern state power involves itself in the biological life of its citizens, was amply illustrated by the various governmental responses to the Covid-19 pandemic. The left-wing academic culture in which his work has long been dominant suddenly found its own influence extending all the way to corporate boardrooms and the halls of the C.I.A. A new volume of his work was published in English: “Confessions of the Flesh,” an exegesis of early Christian sexual morality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Brooklyn Museum Employees Take Steps Toward a Union
description: The new union would include curators, conservators, gift shop workers and others, as part of the U.A.W.
content: Employees at yet another of New York City’s major museums have taken steps to form a union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Crisis of Anti-Semitic Violence
description: A disaster for Jews and a gift to the right.
content: Violence between Jews and Muslims in the Middle East is often accompanied by spikes in anti-Semitic activity in the United States, but what’s happened over the last week or so has been different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: The Best View for the Supermoon May Be on This Plane
description: Qantas will run a one-time scenic flight from Sydney to offer ideal viewing of the supermoon.
content: Australians will have some of the best views of the “super blood moon” this week, but passengers on a one-time flight departing from Sydney will have an even better one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Hughes
title: Scientists Drove Mice to Bond by Zapping Their Brains With Light
description: The study, a tour de force in bioengineering, comes after two decades of research on brain-to-brain synchrony in people.
content: Late one evening last March, just before the coronavirus pandemic shut down the country, Mingzheng Wu, a graduate student at Northwestern University, plopped two male mice into a cage and watched as they explored their modest new digs: sniffing, digging, fighting a little.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Chakravartty and Ajantha Subramanian
title: Why Is Caste Inequality Still Legal in America?
description: This discrimination  is real, and federal law should reflect that.
content: Caste is not well understood in the United States, even though it plays a significant role in the lives of Americans of South Asian descent. Two recent lawsuits make caste among the South Asian diaspora much more visible. They show that oppressed castes in the United States are doubly disadvantaged — by caste and race. Making caste a protected category under federal law will allow for the recognition of this double disadvantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheelah Kolhatkar
title: Juul Wanted to Disrupt Big Tobacco. Instead It Created an Epidemic of Addiction.
description: In “The Devil’s Playbook,” Lauren Etter tells the story of the rise and fall of the start-up that tried to upend the cigarette industry.
content: THE DEVIL’S PLAYBOOKBig Tobacco, Juul, and the Addiction of a New GenerationBy Lauren Etter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton and Sapna Maheshwari
title: Ready to Return: Fashion Rental Is Back
description: The pandemic hit the world of clothing rental hard. Now, companies like Rent the Runway say the market is booming like never before.
content: It’s been more than a year since the coronavirus brought events and socializing to a screeching halt, prompting much of the United States to settle into sweatpants and stay indoors for months on end. Yet in recent weeks — and particularly in parts of the country where life is edging back toward normalcy — there is a post-pandemic ebullience emerging in how Americans are dressing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Justice Dept. Fights to Keep Secret a Memo on Clearing Trump in Russia Inquiry
description: The move put the Biden administration in the position of defending the secrecy of a memo related to the disputed decision to clear President Donald J. Trump.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has decided to fight a legal battle to keep secret most of a Trump-era Justice Department memo related to Attorney General William P. Barr’s much-disputed declaration in 2019 that cleared President Donald J. Trump of illegally obstructing justice in the Russia investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Opens California’s Coast to Wind Farms
description: The idea of erecting wind farms in the Pacific Ocean has long been dismissed as impractical. But major hurdles, including military objections, have now been cleared.
content: WASHINGTON — The notion of wind farms churning in the Pacific Ocean, creating clean energy to power homes and businesses, has long been dismissed because of logistical challenges posed by a deep ocean floor and  opposition from the military, which prefers no obstacles for its Navy ships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Moderna Vaccine Highly Effective in Adolescents, Company Says
description: The U.S., which has a surplus of vaccines, could soon have two options for teens while many countries face shortages.
content: Moderna said on Tuesday that its coronavirus vaccine, authorized only for use in adults, was powerfully effective in 12- to 17-year-olds. In a clinical trial of the vaccine in adolescents, there were no cases of symptomatic Covid-19 among fully vaccinated teens, the company reported in a news release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geneva Abdul
title: Catarina Macario Is Just Getting Started
description: Born in Brazil, developed in the United States and now a pro in France, the 21-year-old forward is proving she belongs alongside the world’s best players.
content: The first steps of Catarina Macario’s path toward professional soccer are easy to pick out, even in the grainy videotapes of her playing the sport as a girl. She doesn’t scissor over the ball so much as dance over it. She darts past defenders or lobs the ball over them. She leaves goalkeepers flat-footed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Who’s Winning the New York Mayor’s Race? Even Pollsters Are Confused.
description: The city’s new system of ranked-choice voting, along with a crowded field of Democrats, has complicated efforts to do comprehensive voter surveys.
content: Much of the focus of the New York City mayoral race has centered on one or two perceived front-runners: Andrew Yang, the 2020 presidential candidate, and Eric Adams, the Brooklyn borough president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Nikole Hannah-Jones Receives Support in Tenure Dispute
description: More than 200 writers and cultural figures signed a letter opposing the University of North Carolina’s failure to give the Times Magazine correspondent tenure with her position there.
content: More than 200 academics, journalists, sports luminaries and other cultural figures published a letter on Tuesday in support of Nikole Hannah-Jones, a correspondent for The New York Times Magazine, who was not offered tenure in her new position at the University of North Carolina by the board of trustees despite a recommendation from its journalism department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: She Built a Baltimore Restaurant Empire, but Still Works the Stove
description: Cindy Wolf is a rarity — a seasoned chef focused on her flagship and a style of white-linen dining that’s been endangered by the pandemic.
content: BALTIMORE — In July of 1999, Cindy Wolf cooked lunch for Julia Child at Charleston, her restaurant on the city’s downtown waterfront. At the end of a five-course meal that included fried oysters with cayenne-lemon mayonnaise and pan-seared sweetbreads, Ms. Wolf went out to the dining room to meet the cooking legend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It OK to Ask Health Care Providers if They’re Vaccinated?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on navigating a world in which vaccination against Covid-19 is both common and contested.
content: Recently, I asked my chiropractor if he had received his Covid vaccine. He said no. He and his assistant do wear masks, but they see patients in a small room with a closed door. When I asked him again several weeks later, he said: “Well, we have to talk. I am not going to get the vaccination. I don’t believe in vaccinations. My family and I are all healthy and see no need for it.” On my way out, I asked his assistant if she had been vaccinated, and she replied: “No, and I don’t plan to. It’s a personal decision.” I called the next morning to explain that I wouldn’t be coming back to their practice because they weren’t vaccinated. Later that day, the chiropractor called and asked me if I would please respect his privacy and not tell anyone else about his decision not to be vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: deforestation
description: This word has appeared in 104 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glynnis MacNicol
title: I Feel Great About My Neck
description: It took me to my mid-40s to learn not to depend on anyone else’s approval of my appearance.
content: Like many of you, I have spent the last 14 months staring at my neck. In all of human history, perhaps no necks (or eyes, or foreheads) have been inspected so relentlessly, and with such attention to detail, as ours collectively have since last March, while working and socializing from home. If Narcissus had been required to look into a high-definition camera, with or without a ring light, for hours each day, would he have been so enamored with his own appearance?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Robbie McCauley, Stage Artist Who Explored Race, Dies at 78
description: Ms. McCauley often put race at the center of plays and other works that sought to alter perspectives and foster dialogue.
content: Robbie McCauley, a performance artist, writer and director who often put race at the center of plays and other works that sought to alter perspectives and foster dialogue, died on Thursday in Silver Spring, Md., where she had been living with her sister, Anita Henderson. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Kentaro Miura, Creator of Epic Manga ‘Berserk,’ Dies at 54
description: For more than 30 years he reached tens of millions of readers worldwide with a fantastical tale of vulnerable characters in an apocalyptic world.
content: Kentaro Miura, who reached a worldwide readership for more than 30 years with his Japanese manga series, “Berserk,” which set the standard for artistic originality and narrative boldness in the fantasy media industry — in card games, comics, video games and animated series — died on May 6. He was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Craig S. Smith
title: Going to the Moon via the Cloud
description: High-performance cloud computing has allowed start-ups to develop prototypes and run simulations — including one to the moon — that were previously done on supercomputers.
content: This article is part of our new series, Currents, which examines how rapid advances in technology are transforming our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $10 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Edgar Sandoval
title: Texas Lawmakers Move to Drop Most Handgun Licensing Requirements
description: The bill would allow most adults over 21 to carry a handgun. Gov. Greg Abbott, who said he would sign it, called it “the strongest Second Amendment legislation in Texas history.”
content: More than a million people in Texas have permits to carry handguns. People often head into grocery stores, barber shops, even college campuses carrying guns for protection. In 2019, when a man in a trench coat opened fire with a shotgun in a suburban church outside of Fort Worth, more than half a dozen people who had gathered for the service responded by drawing their own firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Veterinary offices go upscale to care for pets (and their owners).
description: More than 12.6 million United States households adopted animals from March to December of last year, according to the American Pet Products Association, helping to propel an increase in visits and revenue to veterinary offices.
content: More than 12.6 million United States households adopted animals from March to December of last year, according to the American Pet Products Association, helping to propel an increase in visits and revenue to veterinary offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: How big is India’s true Covid toll?
content: Last week, India recorded the largest daily coronavirus death toll for any country during the pandemic — a figure that most likely is still an undercount. The Times consulted more than a dozen experts to arrive at several possible estimates for the true scale of devastation from Covid-19 in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
title: State Revenues Pour In, Raising Pressure on Biden to Divert Federal Aid
description: Unexpected receipts, driven in part by taxes on high earners riding a hot stock market, have prompted Republicans to push the president to spend on infrastructure instead.
content: WASHINGTON — From California to Virginia, many states that faced devastating shortfalls in the depths of the pandemic recession now find themselves flush with tax revenues because of a rebounding economy and a soaring stock market. Lawmakers who worried about budget cuts are now proposing lucrative increases in school spending, tax cuts and direct payments to their residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Knicks’ Julius Randle Wins N.B.A.’s Most Improved Player Award
description: Randle led the Knicks in scoring and fueled their run to the No. 4 seed in the Eastern Conference.
content: Julius Randle can claim another accolade after his unexpected leap to stardom this season. He is the winner of the N.B.A.’s Most Improved Player Award.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Stanley Reed
title: European airlines respond to the forced landing of a commercial flight in Belarus.
description: Air France, KLM and Finnair said they would suspend flights going through the country’s airspace.
content: More airlines responded on Tuesday to the brazen decision over the weekend by Belarus’s president to force a commercial flight to land in an effort to arrest a dissident journalist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: The Justice Dept. will fight to keep secret most of a Barr-era memo on whether Trump obstructed the Russia inquiry.
description: The move put the Biden administration in the position of defending the secrecy of a memo related to the disputed decision to clear President Donald J. Trump.
content: The Biden administration has decided to fight to keep secret most of a Trump-era Justice Department memo related to former Attorney General William P. Barr’s much-disputed declaration in 2019 clearing President Donald J. Trump of illegally obstructing justice in the Russia investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Sex Is Our Antidote to Loss’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Thursday mornings: Clear our schedules, send the kids off to school. Clutching espressos, tiptoe upstairs to make out like teenagers eluding the chaperone. Forget your cancer scare. Forget how I was widowed by a suicide before you appeared. Sex is our antidote to loss. We take our time. But in the pandemic? No longer. Teenagers fill the house, flung across chairs, splayed on sofas, Zooming — all day. And nighttime? Sleep is sexier than sex. Until school resumes. You touch my face. We lock eyes, holding on, like survivors do, attuned to moments that make days, never wanting to let go. — Rachel Zimmerman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: With ‘Younger’ and ‘The Bold Type’ Ending, Will TV Turn the Page?
description: Series have long depicted media jobs as glitzy and aspirational. But with several such shows wrapping up as much of the news and publishing business craters, is this the end of an era?
content: Joanna Coles published her first magazine at 11 and mailed a copy to Queen Elizabeth. She received a letter of thanks and a royal request for further issues. “It was all the encouragement I needed,” Coles said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Tig Notaro, Action-Hero Heartthrob, Gets Her Blasts From the Past
description: The comedian and actor, who battles zombies in “Army of the Dead,” talks about why she hopes Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell never break up, and more.
content: As a stand-up comic, Tig Notaro is used to doing plenty of things on her own. But acting out an entire zombie thriller in front of a green screen, without her co-stars, isn’t one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: One Year Later
description: On the anniversary of George Floyd’s murder, we examine its legacy so far.
content: Shortly after 8 p.m. on May 25, 2020, Derek Chauvin, a Minneapolis police officer, placed his knee on George Floyd’s neck and kept it there for more than nine minutes. None of the three other officers standing near Chauvin intervened. Soon, Floyd was dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Isabel Kershner
title: Seeking to Restore Palestinian Links, Blinken Risks New Frictions With Israel
description: The U.S. secretary of state drew thanks from Israeli officials for supporting their right to self-defense against Hamas. But he risked angering Israel in his diplomatic outreach to Palestinians.
content: RAMALLAH, West Bank —  America’s top diplomat came to the seat of the Palestinian government on Tuesday with promises of additional aid, a reopened consulate in Jerusalem and a broad sympathetic pledge to rebuild ties that had been severed by the previous administration in favor of Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: A Year After George Floyd, Los Angeles Confronts Its Future and Its Past
description: Tuesday: Los Angeles has been struggling to respond to both calls for racial justice and a surge in gun violence.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Big Deal in Amazon’s Antitrust Case
description: The claim that Amazon is crushing competition is both novel and railroad baron-style old-school.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: A History of Baseball’s Modern Era in Four Umpires
description: With Joe West breaking Bill Klem’s record for games, a look at four umpires who can connect 1905 to 2021.
content: When Joe West took the field for Tuesday night’s game between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Chicago White Sox, it was his 5,376th appearance. Having started his major league career in 1976, he now stands alone as the umpire to have worked the most games in major league history, breaking a record that has stood for 80 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Greene’s Holocaust Comparisons Cause New Headaches for G.O.P.
description: Republican leaders condemned the latest anti-Semitic statements by Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, but their slow response and refusal to punish her reflected tacit backing.
content: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders on Tuesday broke nearly a week of silence about comments by Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia comparing mask and vaccine mandates to the treatment of Jews by Nazis during the Holocaust, condemning her language but stopping short of punishing her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: John Cena Apologizes to China for Calling Taiwan a Country
description: Mr. Cena, a star of the newest “Fast and Furious” movie, posted a video apology in Mandarin, saying, “I’m really sorry. You have to understand that I love and respect China.”
content: John Cena, the professional wrestler and a star of “F9,” the latest installment in the “Fast and Furious” franchise, apologized to fans in China on Tuesday after he referred to Taiwan as a country while giving a promotional interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Orange
title: A Novel Explores Power, Sex, Consent and Identity on a French Commune
description: In Emmanuelle Bayamack-Tam’s novel “Arcadia,” one teenager seeks self-awareness while living on a commune ruled by a hedonistic leader.
content: ARCADIABy Emmanuelle Bayamack-TamTranslated by Ruth Diver
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Where Poets Are Being Killed and Jailed After a Military Coup
description: More than 30 poets have been imprisoned since the military seized power in Myanmar, a country where politics and poetry are intimately connected.
content: After the first and second poets were killed, the third poet wrote a poem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Youngest U.K. Lawmaker Takes a Break, Citing PTSD
description: Nadia Whittome said that it was important to be honest about her mental health struggles in the hope that it would normalize talking about the issue.
content: LONDON — The youngest member of Britain’s Parliament, Nadia Whittome, said she would take several weeks off on the advice of her doctor after being diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder, in a candid statement that has shined a spotlight on mental health issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Nicholas Fandos
title: Why the Capitol Riot Inquiries Leave Room for a Broader Commission
description: Republicans have argued that the existing Justice Department and congressional investigations will address the assault. But they have strict limits.
content: As the Senate moves this week toward voting on the creation of a 9/11-style commission to investigate the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, Republicans have raised a series of arguments against it. They have objected to the inquiry’s scope, its length and even the process for hiring its staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Injuries Stacking Up as Mets Lose to Rockies
description: The team is up to 16 players on the injured list and at least one more will likely be added on Tuesday.
content: Austin Gomber pitched two-hit ball through eight innings, Ryan McMahon and Elias Diaz hit second-inning home runs off David Peterson and the Colorado Rockies beat the banged-up Mets, 3-2, Monday night for just their third win in 20 road games this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: The End of Online Classes
description: Masks will still be required, and schools will follow social-distancing guidelines, but vaccinations are not yet mandatory.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Mount Sinai Seeks to Expand School Virus Testing Program
description: The health system, which is preparing to open a new laboratory that could process 100,000 tests a day, wants to take its program to public schools this fall.
content: Every week, students at KIPP Infinity Middle School, in West Harlem, file into a large auditorium and take their places on the designated floor markings, making sure to stand six feet apart. Then they pull down their masks and fill sterile tubes with their spit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Chicago Priest to Be Reinstated After Inquiry Finds Proof of Sex Abuse Lacking
description: There is “insufficient reason to suspect” that the Rev. Michael Pfleger is guilty, the Archdiocese of Chicago announced.
content: The Rev. Michael Pfleger, an influential Roman Catholic priest who temporarily stepped aside from his parish on the South Side of Chicago in January after he was accused of sexually abusing a minor more than 40 years ago, will be reinstated after an internal investigation found “insufficient reason to suspect” he was guilty, the Archdiocese of Chicago announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Jett
title: Mark York, Actor on ‘The Office,’ Dies at 55
description: The Ohio native, who advocated greater visibility onscreen for people with disabilities, appeared in early seasons of the NBC sitcom as Billy Merchant.
content: Mark York, the actor best known for playing Billy Merchant on the NBC sitcom “The Office,” died last week in Dayton, Ohio. He was 55.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: The Small Business Administration’s Gaffes Are Now Her Job to Fix
description: Traditionally a federal backwater, the agency has stumbled while shepherding $1 trillion in emergency aid. Its leader vows “a more customer-first approach.”
content: Isabella Casillas Guzman, President Biden’s choice to run the Small Business Administration, inherited a portfolio of nearly $1 trillion in emergency aid and an agency plagued by controversy when she took over in March. She has been sprinting from crisis to crisis ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: On the Verge of Two Million Runs
description: There was much fanfare in 1975 when Bob Watson scored baseball’s millionth run. With baseball’s historical stats in flux, the two millionth will score this week without much fuss.
content: For 145 years, players have stepped, slid, walked, tumbled and jumped on white rubber slabs all over the continent. It is the act of scoring a run, the objective of baseball, and it is adding up to an impending milestone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: Suspicious package delivered to Rand Paul’s home is under investigation.
description: Senator Rand Paul condemned the package on Twitter, saying he took the “threats immensely seriously.”
content: The F.B.I and Capitol Police are investigating a package that was sent to Senator Rand Paul’s home in Bowling Green, Ky., on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘An Invitation to the Cicada Party’
description: Billions of cicadas, part of a group called Brood X, have begun to emerge after spending 17 years underground. In this lesson, students will learn more about these insects and why they’ve chosen this moment to make their debut.
content: Featured Article: “An Invitation to the Cicada Party” by Eleanor Lutz
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: One Irish Poet Looks Back Three Centuries to Find Obsession and Inspiration in Another
description: In “A Ghost in the Throat,” Doireann Ni Ghriofa combines essay, biography and autofiction in writing about (and translating) a passionate 18th-century lament.
content: A woman once fell in love with a poem — a keening, a roaring — for a slain beloved. The 18th-century Irish noblewoman Eibhlin Dubh Ni Chonaill composed “Caoineadh Airt Ui Laoghaire” after her husband was murdered by a powerful British official. Arriving at the scene, Ni Chonaill, pregnant with their third child, drank handfuls of her husband’s blood. “My bright dove,” “my pleasure,” she called him in the poem, “my thousand bewilderments” — why hadn’t she been with him? She imagined her blouse catching the bullet in its pleats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Malaysia Train Collision Injures More Than 200 People
description: A light rail train carrying passengers in Kuala Lumpur collided in a tunnel with an empty train on a test run. Officials promised a full investigation.
content: More than 200 people were injured in Malaysia’s largest city, Kuala Lumpur, on Monday when a train full of passengers collided head-on in a tunnel with another train on a test run, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Delaware Senator Turns D.C. Power Broker (That’s Right: Chris Coons)
description: A top ally of President Biden’s has major responsibilities as the clock ticks on the White House’s agenda and bipartisanship proves elusive.
content: Roll the clock back a few decades, and the longtime junior senator from Delaware was often at the heart of negotiations on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The E.U. moves to restrict Belarus’s air access.
content: The E.U. yesterday urged airlines to avoid Belarus’s airspace and pledged to impose sanctions on Aleksandr Lukashenko, the country’s strongman leader, a day after Belarus brazenly forced down a Ryanair commercial airliner so it could seize a dissident journalist onboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: Biden will meet with George Floyd’s family on the anniversary of his death.
description: The George Floyd Justice in Policing Act is languishing in Congress, but the White House is optimistic that legislative talks will help move it forward.
content: President Biden will meet on Tuesday with relatives of George Floyd to mark the anniversary of his death and the start of a nationwide racial reckoning against police brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Roman Protasevich: A Belarus Activist Who ‘Refused to Live in Fear’
description: Disgusted by the brutality of President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, Mr. Protasevich bravely embarked at 16 on a life in opposition.
content: WARSAW — Since his teenage years as a rebellious high school student in Belarus and continuing into his 20s while in exile abroad, Roman Protasevich faced so many threats from the country’s security apparatus — of violent beatings, jail, punishment against family members — that “we all sort of got used to them,” a fellow exiled dissident recalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Taiwan Was a Covid Haven for Performers. Then Cases Flared.
description: One of the few places where performances continued steadily for much of the pandemic has had to shut down theaters just as they are reopening elsewhere.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — For much of the past year, Taiwan has been a sanctuary for performing artists, the rare almost-Covid-free place where audiences could cram into concert halls to hear live music and sip coffee together at intermission.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘An Out-of-Body Experience’: Inside India’s Covid Crisis
description: Fear, grief and boredom pervade the lives of those contending with the country’s severe outbreak. Their solace: family, friends and their own efforts to help others.
content: Infections are soaring. So are deaths. Whole cities are under lockdown. And the government seems powerless to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: The Curious World of NFT Real Estate and Design
description: People are selling and buying art, furniture and even houses and land that exist only virtually.
content: It’s not uncommon for people to buy vacation homes they may only visit a few times a year. What about a home you never visit? And that doesn’t actually exist?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: Republicans in Arizona and Georgia are still trying to delegitimize the election.
description: Efforts to question the legitimacy of the 2020 election in two swing states, nearly seven months after voting concluded, illustrate former President Donald J. Trump’s continued hold over the Republican Party and the staying power of his false election claims.
content: Efforts to question the legitimacy of the 2020 election in two swing states, nearly seven months after voting concluded, illustrate former President Donald J. Trump’s continued hold over the Republican Party and the staying power of his false election claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox News will replay prime-time shows on its streaming service.
description: The cable programs can attract new subscribers and widen their viewership to younger audiences.
content: Fox News entered the streaming video market in November 2018 with Fox Nation, a digital subscription service that now encompasses hundreds of hours of original programming including political commentary, documentaries and travel specials like “Castles USA,” in which the host Jeanine Pirro tours castles around the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Joel Chadabe, Explorer of Electronic Music’s Frontier, Dies at 82
description: As both a composer and an advocate, Mr. Chadabe devoted himself to what one music critic called the “marriage between humans and their computers.”
content: Joel Chadabe, a composer who helped pioneer electronic music in the 1960s, later developing compositional software programs and founding the Electronic Music Foundation, an advocacy organization for electronic music, died on May 2 at his home in Albany, N.Y. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Biden Seeks to Replace Several Trump Appointees on Arts Commission
description: Several members of the Commission of Fine Arts were asked to step down, including its chairman, who promoted classical architecture as the preferred style for federal buildings.
content: Four of the seven members of the federal Commission of Fine Arts, a generally low-key, earnest design advisory group that became embroiled in battles over architectural style during the Trump era, have been told by the Biden administration to resign or face termination, according to the commission’s chairman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Party Line
description: Kristian House and Mike Dockins just can’t believe it.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — One of the questions I get asked quite often is “What does it mean when clues use quotation marks or brackets?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismail Muhammad
title: From Fatwa to Fabulism: Salman Rushdie Takes Stock of the 21st Century So Far
description: “Languages of Truth” collects essays and speeches written between 2003 and 2020.
content: LANGUAGES OF TRUTH Essays 2003-2020 By Salman Rushdie
source.name: The New York Times

title: Silicon Valley is resetting expectations for self-driving cars and settling in for years of more work.
description: After years of hype, billions of dollars of investments and promises that people would be commuting to work in self-driving cars by now, the pursuit of autonomous cars is undergoing a reset.
content: After years of hype, billions of dollars of investments and promises that people would be commuting to work in self-driving cars by now, the pursuit of autonomous cars is undergoing a reset.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Cheerleader, a Snapchat Post and the Supreme Court
description: Inside the unusual sequence of events behind one of the most important student free speech cases for 50 years.
content: On a Saturday in 2017, Brandi Levy, then 14, was having a bad day. She hadn’t made the varsity cheerleading squad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: Pentagon Accelerates Withdrawal From Afghanistan
description: American troops are set to be out by early to mid-July, well ahead of President Biden’s Sept. 11 deadline, even as big issues remain unresolved.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — United States troops and their NATO allies intend to be out of Afghanistan by early to mid-July, well ahead of President Biden’s Sept. 11 withdrawal deadline, military officials said, in what has turned into an accelerated ending to America’s longest war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Greenberg
title: Was Richard Nixon a Tragic Hero?
description: Michael Dobbs’s “King Richard” tells the story of the first few months after Nixon’s second inaugural, when his eventual downfall was becoming clear.
content: KING RICHARD
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: How to Vote in the New York City Primary in June
description: New Yorkers hoping to select candidates for mayor and a range of other offices must first make sure they can vote. The deadline to register is this Friday, May 28.
content: In exactly four weeks, residents of New York City will cast ballots in a primary election with profound implications for the city’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: With Tokyo Olympics Weeks Away, U.S. Warns Americans Not to Travel to Japan
description: The move’s effects are likely to be minimal, as Japan’s borders are largely shut because of the pandemic and American athletes are expected to participate in the Games regardless.
content: WASHINGTON — The State Department on Monday warned Americans against traveling to Japan as the country experiences an increase in coronavirus cases less than two months before the start of the Tokyo Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Gayle
title: 100 Years After the Tulsa Massacre, What Does Justice Look Like?
description: In 1921, a white mob attacked the Greenwood district of Tulsa, killing hundreds of Black people and destroying the neighborhood. Justice has never been served. Can it still be today?
content: As dusk was falling on Sept. 16, 2016, callers began dialing 9-1-1 to report that a Lincoln Navigator had been abandoned on 36th Street North in Tulsa, Okla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Archaeologists vs. Computers: A Study Tests Who’s Best at Sifting the Past
description: When it came to the tedious task of categorizing pottery fragments, a deep-learning model was found to be just as accurate, and far more efficient, as four human experts.
content: A key piece of an archaeologist’s job involves the tedious process of categorizing shards of pottery into subtypes. Ask archaeologists why they have put a fragment into a particular category and it’s often difficult for them to say what exactly had led them to that conclusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden faces pressure to stop Trump-era border expulsions.
description: President Biden is coming under increasing pressure to abandon a Trump-era immigration rule that has sealed off the United States to most migrants during the pandemic, with human rights officials and two of the administration’s own medical consultants saying it endangers vulnerable families.
content: President Biden is coming under increasing pressure to abandon a Trump-era immigration rule that has sealed off the United States to most migrants during the pandemic, with human rights officials and two of the administration’s own medical consultants saying it endangers vulnerable families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Day 7: Brush Your Way to a New Habit
description: Your daily tooth-brushing routine is a great opportunity to schedule a new goal. Today, try doing calf raises, squats or lunges for a burst of exercise while you brush your teeth. Use the time to meditate by focusing on the taste of the toothpaste and sound of the water. Or schedule push-ups, a wall sit or yoga for after you’ve finished.
content: Your daily tooth-brushing routine is a great opportunity to schedule a new goal. Today, try doing calf raises, squats or lunges for a burst of exercise while you brush your teeth. Use the time to meditate by focusing on the taste of the toothpaste and sound of the water. Or schedule push-ups, a wall sit or yoga for after you’ve finished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: When to Watch a Lunar Eclipse and Supermoon in Late Night Skies
description: People out west in the United States and in Australia and East Asia will have a good view of an event some call a “super blood moon.”
content: Night owls in California and other points out west are in for a treat on May 26 as the moon enters Earth’s shadow and turns a blood red color during a total lunar eclipse, the first in more than two years visible from the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: ‘Myths and Hymns,’ a Theater Cult Favorite, Changes Shape Again
description: Adam Guettel’s genre-clashing song cycle has taken on many forms. The latest: a starry online mini-series.
content: Listening to Adam Guettel’s song cycle “Myths and Hymns,” after a year of pandemic isolation and cautiously hoping for vaccinated freedom, you might feel a pang of recognition in the lyric “So get me up, and get me out, and let me never return,” swelling to “I’m out of here/I am going there/I am gone!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Vets Go Upscale to Care for Pets (and Their Owners)
description: The pet boom spurred by the pandemic has brought more attention to care for our four-legged friends. Veterinary companies are opening clinics, drawing more investors to vet real estate.
content: When Allegra Brochin and her boyfriend adopted Sprinkles, a feisty white Maltese, last year, they set about finding pet care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert: Rand Paul ‘Randsplained’ His Vaccine Refusal
description: “Senator Paul has been a bit of a skeptic of how bad Covid really is, which is probably why he got Covid,” Colbert said on Monday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Revival Season,’ by Monica West: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Revival Season,” by Monica West
content: We had been standing close to this exact spot on the night when she’d asked me to heal her. Breathless, I approached Dawn’s closed passenger door and banged on the window. She opened it and stepped outside; I followed her around the side of the car to the rusted trunk. Her face had more color in it, her cheeks chubbier, her breathing at normal intervals as she spoke to me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Gillibrand teams up with Hawley on a measure to combat sexual assault in the military.
description: The lawmakers are on opposite ends of nearly all things political, but they are working together on a bill designed to improve the military’s response to sexual assault.
content: One of the most interesting new alliances in the Senate these days is between Senator Kirsten Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, and Senator Josh Hawley, Republican of Missouri, who have been working together on the Senate Armed Services Committee on possible solutions to sexual assault in the military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Andrés R. Martínez
title: ‘On the Ashes of Tragedy’: Mixed Emotions on Anniversary of George Floyd’s Death
description: The crowds that gathered in Minneapolis and elsewhere reflected on what has changed, and what has not, in America since Mr. Floyd was murdered by a police officer.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — It was a day of reflection, of remembrance, a time to lay flowers and say prayers, to celebrate Black culture with art and music and food, and to recall the life of a man whose death, one year ago, shook the country and forced it to confront its painful legacy of racism and police brutality.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Living Sea of Waking Dreams,’ by Richard Flanagan: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Living Sea of Waking Dreams,” by Richard Flanagan
content: Her hand.

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Iraqi Activism Fights for Survival Amid Murders and Threats
description: A movement demanding a new kind of Iraq struggles to carry on, despite intimidation from Iranian-backed militias that are believed to have murdered dozens of activists.
content: BAGHDAD — ‘Who killed me?’ the signs asked, alongside images of dead men and women, among the roughly 80 Iraqi activists murdered since late 2019. Young demonstrators held aloft the posters in Baghdad’s Tahrir Square on Tuesday, illustrating both the enduring spark and diminished strength of Iraq’s anti-government protest movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: Meet the 12 High Schoolers Who Won a New York Times Scholarship This Year
description: The students, all New York City high school seniors, will each receive $15,000 per year to help pay for college.
content: Jenifer Weng still hates the sound of a phone ringing. To her, it’ll always mean “Get back to work.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lois Henry and Ryan Christopher Jones
title: The Central California Town That Keeps Sinking
description: The very ground upon which Corcoran, Calif., was built has been slowly but steadily collapsing, a situation caused primarily not by nature but agriculture.
content: CORCORAN, Calif. — In California’s San Joaquin Valley, the farming town of Corcoran has a multimillion-dollar problem. It is almost impossible to see, yet so vast it takes NASA scientists using satellite technology to fully grasp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Coons, Biden’s Eyes and Ears in the Senate, Reaches for Bipartisanship
description: The Delaware Democrat, who once interned for President Biden, is now his main conduit to senators in both parties who hold the key to moving his agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Chris Coons, Democrat of Delaware, was hurrying to a vote through the Capitol’s cavernous underground tunnel system on a recent Thursday when his phone rang. It was Pete Buttigieg, the secretary of transportation, calling for a quick briefing before an infrastructure meeting he had scheduled with a group of Republican senators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Is the Bitcoin Craze Coming for Your 401(k)?
description: Cryptocurrencies haven’t quite delivered on their revolutionary promises. But they are messing with the stock market.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

author: By Elian Peltier and Ruth Maclean
title: Military Ousts Civilian Leaders in Mali
description: The interim president and prime minister, appointed to oversee preparations for elections next year, were detained. Nine months ago, another coup toppled the previous president.
content: Military officials in Mali ousted the country’s interim civilian leaders on Tuesday, setting up a new crisis for the West African nation, just nine months after the previous president was forced out in a military coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: C.D.C. Will Not Investigate Mild Infections in Vaccinated Americans
description: At least 10,000 vaccinated people were infected with the coronavirus through the end of April. Now the agency has stopped pursuing the mildest cases.
content: Julie Cohn was fully vaccinated when she went to cheer at her 12-year-old son’s basketball game in March. Midway through the match, he asked to remove his mask because he was getting so hot. She thought little of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe, Karen Weise and Cecilia Kang
title: D.C. Accuses Amazon of Controlling Online Prices
description: The District of Columbia said in a lawsuit that Amazon had stopped merchants that use its platform from charging lower prices for the same products elsewhere online.
content: WASHINGTON — The District of Columbia sued Amazon on Tuesday, accusing it of artificially raising prices for products around the web by abusing its monopoly power, a sign that regulators in the United States are increasingly turning their attention to the company’s dominance across the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David L. Kirp
title: Community College Should Be More Than Just Free
description: For Biden's community college plan  to work, students are going to need a holistic system of support, not just free tuition.
content: Free community college for everyone is the centerpiece of President Biden’s $302 billion, 10-year investment in expanding access to higher education. Though it has been hailed as a revolutionary proposal, this walking-through-the-door access doesn’t solve higher education’s biggest challenge — boosting the number of community college students who graduate or transfer to a four-year school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Union Square Hospitality Group’s Ci Siamo to Open
description: Rick Bayless makes his New York debut; a rotating cast of chefs work from a former Greenpoint laundromat; and more restaurant news.
content: This major restaurant from Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group is set to open in Manhattan West, the multiblock Brookfield Properties development opposite Hudson Yards, in September. It will be the group’s first new restaurant in New York City since Manhatta in 2018. The executive chef will be Hillary Sterling, 42, the executive chef at Vic’s in NoHo for the past seven years where she became known for her take on Italian food. She was at A Voce Madison before that. Mr. Meyer named the new restaurant after an expression that can mean “Here we are!” or “We’ve arrived!” in Italian, and, following suit, the menu will also be Italian with touches of France. Ms. Sterling said she would strive for simplicity, something that has increasingly informed her cooking. Pastas, like pappardelle with rabbit, will be essential, she said, but there will be no pizzas. Her wood-fired grill, a kitchen centerpiece, will sear vegetables, seafood and meats, like a crispy chicken with potatoes. The restaurant, on the second floor of a building at the center of the development, will seat 120, including outdoor tables on a terrace. A bar and lounge, where Ms. Sterling plans to serve aperitivo snacks, will have another 40 seats. Event space will take up part of the third floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadja Spiegelman
title: Bullied and Shunned, They Found a New Way to See the World
description: In “Heaven,” by Mieko Kawakami, two teenagers find solace and meaning in the face of ruthless torment.

author: By Diana Buttu
title: The Myth of Coexistence in Israel
description: Palestinians live under a racist system whose laws enshrine their second-class status.
content: Secretary of State Antony Blinken is visiting Israel and plans to visit the West Bank in an attempt to bolster Friday’s cease-fire, which halted Israel’s bombing campaign in Gaza and Hamas’s rocket attacks on Israel. On Tuesday, Mr. Blinken spoke in Jerusalem about his intention to “rally international support” to aid Gaza and rebuild what was destroyed.

author: By Noah Weiland and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Chiquita Brooks-LaSure becomes the first Black administrator confirmed to lead Medicare and Medicaid.
description: The vote was 55 to 44, with five Republicans joining Democrats to support her confirmation.
content: The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Chiquita Brooks-LaSure, a former Obama administration health official, to lead the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, one of the most powerful posts at the Department of Health and Human Services. The vote was 55 to 44, with five Republicans joining Democrats to support her confirmation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 25, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, May 25, 2021.
content: The Quote of the Day on Saturday, taken from a front-page story about residents in several Oregon counties backing a plan to secede and join Idaho, misidentified the university where Bruce A. Weber had been the director of the Rural Studies Program. As the article correctly stated, Mr. Weber led the program at Oregon State University, not the University of Oregon.
